questions.question: Transovarial transmission is a feature of which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation: Transovarial transmission occurs when a pathogen is passed from a parent, usually the mother, to its offspring via eggs, which is a characteristic of scrub typhus.

questions.question: A 36-year-old trekker presented with fever, headache, and rashes following a tick bite. He waslater diagnosed to have Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Which of the following statements isfalse about the microbe implicated?
questions.explanation: Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii. A cell wall is present in rickettsialorganisms.Rickettsiae are obligate intracellular, gram-negative pleomorphic coccobacilli. They are unable togrow in cell-free media and are thus cultured in yolk sacs of embryonated eggs. They arenon-motile, non-capsulated organisms that contain both DNA and RNA. They reproduce bybinary fission and are transmitted by arthropods like ticks and lice (except Coxiella burnetii andBartonella henselae).The rickettsiae are localized in endothelial cells of small blood vessels (except Ehrlichia andAnaplasma) in humans. They cause endothelial cell enlargement and degeneration, predisposing307to thrombus formation. Tetracyclines, macrolides, and fluoroquinolones are effective against thisgroup but, beta-lactams are ineffective.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding endemic murine typhus?

options.B: It is caused by R. prowazekii

questions.explanation: The vector for endemic murine typhus is the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis. Endemic murine typhus is caused by Rickettsia typhi (not option B) while epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The zoonotic reservoir for R. typhi is the rat. Humans are infected when flea feces contaminate pruritic bite lesions. Transmission can also occur via inhalation of aerosols of dried feces of rickettsemic rat flea. No man-to-man transmission occurs. Patients present with fever, chills, vomiting, and a maculopapular rash that is more prominent on the trunk. Diagnosis is by serology and treatment is with doxycycline. When male guinea pigs are inoculated intraperitoneally with blood from a case of endemic typhus, they develop fever and a characteristic scrotal inflammation. The scrotum becomes enlarged and the testes cannot be pushed into the abdomen. This is known as the Neil-Mooser reaction. It is positive with Rickettsia typhi (not option D) and negative with Rickettsia prowazekii.

questions.question: Multiple inmates at a prison are suspected to have epidemic typhus following an arthropod infestation. Which of the following vectors is implicated in the spread of this disease?
questions.explanation: Louse (Pediculus humanus corporis) transmits epidemic typhus. Gaol fever/Jail fever/epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. Vectors of Rickettsia include the louse.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man from Kashmir presents with fever, chills, and rash for 1 week. The rash appeared on the 5th day of the fever, starting from the trunk and progressing to the limbs. Epidemic typhus is suspected. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the disease?

options.B: Brill-Zinsser disease is a recrudescent form
options.C: Rash is present on palms and soles

questions.explanation: Epidemic typhus rash spares the palms and soles. Epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, is transmitted by the louse Pediculus humanus corporis. There is no transovarial transmission of R. prowazekii. The disease spreads through infected louse feces deposited when the louse feeds on the human host. It is commonly seen in poor, unhygienic, or cold conditions. Epidemic typhus starts with fever and chills. A characteristic rash appears on the fourth or fifth day, starting on the trunk and spreading over the limbs but sparing the face, palms, and soles. In some patients who recover from epidemic typhus, the rickettsiae may remain latent in the lymphoid tissues or organs for years. Such latent infection may, at times, be reactivated, leading to recrudescent typhus (Brill-Zinsser disease). Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. It occurs with Orientia tsutsugamushi, Rickettsia rickettsii, R. conorii, and R. akari. Note: Rash on palms and soles is typically described in Rocky Mountain spotted fever, secondary syphilis, and hand, foot, and mouth disease.

questions.question: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
questions.explanation: The drug of choice for scrub typhus is doxycycline. To treat scrub typhus, oral doxycycline 100 mg is given twice daily for 7-15 days. In the case of pregnant women, oral azithromycin 500 mg for 3 days may be used as doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy. Scrub typhus is a rickettsial infection caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is a trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1-3 weeks. Patients develop a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. It can be associated with fever, headache, myalgia, meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonia. Serologic assays are used for diagnosis. Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction used for diagnosis, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of Proteus strains OX19, OX2, and OXK. OXK alone is agglutinated in scrub typhus.

questions.question: A 25-year-old man came with complaints of fever and a skin lesion as shown below. He givesa history of hiking in scrub forests a week prior, where he suffered an insect bite. Onexamination, there is regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash. Which of thefollowing arthropods is involved in the spread of this disease?EIGRIF0
questions.explanation: A history of contact with scrub vegetation with fever, regional lymphadenopathy, maculopapularrash, and eschar at the bite site is suggestive of scrub typhus.Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by trombiculid mite.Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7-14 days is the drug of choice for treatment of scrub typhus in adults.In case of pregnant women and children, azithromycin or chloramphenicol may be preferredwhere doxycycline is relatively contraindicated.310

questions.explanation: In the above clinical scenario, a history of insect bite followed by the development of acharacteristic eschar at the site of the bite and a positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutininssuggests a diagnosis of scrub typhus.Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested foragglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2, and OX K. questions.question: A veterinarian presents with new-onset mitral regurgitation and fever. An echo reveals valvevegetations and blood cultures show no growth. Q fever is suspected. Which of the followingstatements is false regarding the organism implicated?
questions.explanation: Coxiella burnetii is the causative organism of Q fever. It is transmitted by ixodid ticks inanimals; however, it is not transmitted to humans via ticks.Coxiella burnetii is a filterable, obligate intracellular pathogen. They are gram-negative but arebetter stained with Gimenez, Giemsa stains. They are heat resistant and hence survive Holder'smethod of pasteurization.Q fever is a zoonosis and the primary source of human infection are infected cattle, sheep, andgoats. It spreads through the inhalational route. Veterinarians are at higher risk due to increasedexposure. Acute disease resembles influenza, nonbacterial (atypical) pneumonia, and hepatitis.Chronic disease presents as culture-negative bacterial endocarditis in patients with valvular heartdisease.

questions.question: A patient presents with redness of the eye and foreign body sensation. On examination, thereis follicular hypertrophy in the lower lids and moderately abundant exudates. Chlamydialinfection is suspected. Which strains could have caused this condition?

options.B: Serotypes A, B, Ba and C

questions.explanation: Redness, foreign body sensation with follicular hypertrophy in the lower lids and moderatelyabundant exudates suggests inclusion conjunctivitis which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatisserotypes D to K.311Inclusion conjunctivitis is a type of acute follicular conjunctivitis caused by C. trachomatisserotypes D to K. The infection is transmitted to the eye from genitals, or contaminated swimmingpools. Patients present with foreign body sensation, redness and mucopurulent discharge. Onexamination, there is acute follicular hypertrophy of the lower palpebral conjunctiva and fornix,non-tender pre-auricularlymphadenopathy and superficial keratitis in upper half of cornea.C. trachomatis is a Gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacteria. It cannot produce ATP. Itcauses a variety of human diseases (ocular and genitourinary) and has two main biologicalvariants:•⚫ TRIC biovar which causes trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis (TRIC biovar). This is furtherdivided into 12 serological variants:• A, B, Ba, C serovars which cause blinding or endemic trachoma•⚫ D to K servovars which cause inclusion conjunctivitisLGV biovar (L1, L2, L3 serotypes) which causes lymphogranuloma venereum

questions.question: A thick, yellowish discharge is noted from the eyes of a five-day-old neonate in the step-downward during rounds. An iodine-stained smear of the exudates is positive for large cytoplasmicinclusions as shown in the image. Which of the following is false about the organismresponsible for the above condition?302
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of a thick yellowish discharge from the eye showing iodine-stainedinclusion bodies is suggestive of inclusion conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Aschlamydia is a bacteria, it possesses both DNA and RNA.Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular organisms that produce basophilic inclusion bodies. Theyare filterable like viruses. They are called energy parasites as they lack enzymes for ATP synthesis.They cannot grow on artificial media but can grow on cell lines like McCoy, HeLa, or the yolk sacof the chick embryo.Chlamydiae occur in two forms, the elementary body and the reticulate body. The extracellular,infective form is called the elementary body. The intracellular, non-infective, growing,and replicative form is called the reticulate body. These are found inside a membrane-boundcompartment called the inclusion body which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells byiodine or Giemsa stain. The cell wall of the reticulate body is fragile and pliable, leadingto pleomorphism.312ElementarybodyLifecycle of Chlamydia72 hoursElementarybodiesEpithelial cellElementarybody12 hoursReticulatebodiesRRO48 hoursOMARROW24 hoursInclusion

questions.question: A poultry worker was admitted to ICU with severe pneumonia. Bronchoalveolar lavage wasdone; it showed Levinthal Cole Lillie bodies. Which of the following is the causative organismfor the above condition?
questions.explanation: Pneumonia in a poultry worker with Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies on bronchoalveolar lavagespecimens is suggestive of psittacosis.Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies are inclusion bodies of Chlamydia psittaci seen in infected cellsincluding alveolar macrophages from patients suffering from psittacosis. C. psittaci can betransmitted to humans by direct contact with infected birds or by inhalation of aerosols fromavian feather dust. Psittacosis presents with fever, chills, muscular aches and pains, severeheadache, hepatosplenomegaly and gastrointestinal symptoms. Severe pneumonia may develop. Itis treated with tetracycline.

questions.question: A patient presented with painful swellings on both sides of the groin as shown in the image.The clinician suspects lymphogranuloma venereum. Which is the most common serovarcausing the above condition?303
questions.explanation: Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused most commonly by Chlamydia trachomatis LGVserovar L2.LGV is a sexually transmitted disease, characterized by suppurative inguinal adenitis.

questions.question: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum?
questions.explanation: The incubation period of Lymphogranuloma venereum ranges from 10-30 days. Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The most common presentation is the inguinal syndrome, which is characterized by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy.

questions.question: Lesion scrapings from a genital ulcer show numerous polymorphs, but no bacteria. Which ofthe following is the most appropriate culture medium for organisms responsible for the abovecondition?
questions.explanation: Clinical scrapings from a genital ulcer showing polymorphs in the absence of bacteria is suggestiveof chlamydial infection and the most appropriate culture medium is McCoy cells (human synovialcarcinoma cell line).C. trachomatis is a small gram-negative bacterium and an obligate intracellular parasite thatappears as an intracytoplasmic inclusion body. The gram stain of the cervical smear would showleucocytes but no organisms. Hence, selective culture media like the McCoy cells culture is used toisolate the organism.Option B: Thayer-Martin agar is used for isolation of Neisseria spp.Option C: Robertson's cooked meat is used for the culture of anaerobes, especially ClostridiaOption D: Pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) broth is used to culture Mycoplasma spp. andUreaplasma spp.Note: Abnormal urethral gram stain showing >10 PMNs/1000Å~ field in women with dysuriabut without coliform bacteriuria supports the diagnosis of chlamydial urethritis.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presented with a 3-day history of mucopurulent cervical discharge.Gram staining of the discharge revealed numerous pus cells, but no organisms. What is theinvestigation of choice for the diagnosis of this infection?
questions.explanation: Mucopurulent cervical discharge for 3 days is suggestive of acute cervicitis. As gram stain does notshow any organism, gonococcal infection is less likely. In this case, Chlamydia trachomatis is themost likely organism. For C. trachomatis, the investigation of choice is the nucleic acidamplification test (NAAT).NAATs are the most sensitive tests to detect chlamydia. These tests also have a high specificitycomparable to culture, and in contrast to culture, do not depend on viable pathogens. Therefore,NAATs are generally considered the test of choice for chlamydia and have replaced culture as thediagnostic gold standard.Mucopurulent cervicitis is the inflammation of the columnar epithelium and subepithelium of theendocervix in women. Its commonly caused by Neiserria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydiatrachomatis.

questions.question: Which of the following microbes is also referred to as Eaton's agent ?
questions.explanation: Eaton's agent refers to Mycoplasma pneumoniae.Eaton was the first to isolate Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Because it was filterable, it wasconsidered to be a virus previously.It was formerly known as PPLO– Pleuro pneumonia-like organism.

questions.question: A 20-year-old military recruit presented with fever, sore throat, and non-productive coughwhich showed no improvement with beta-lactam antibiotics. X-ray showed peribronchialpneumonia with thickened bronchial markings. Primary atypical pneumonia is suspected.Which of the following statements is false regarding the organism responsible for thiscondition?
questions.explanation: 314The above clinical scenario of fever, non-productive cough, no improvement with beta-lactamantibiotics along with X-ray features showing peribronchial pneumonia with thickened bronchialmarkings is suggestive of Mycoplasma pneumonia, also known as primary atypical pneumonia orwalking pneumonia.Mycoplasmas are not obligate intracellular parasites. They are free-living bacteria devoid of cellwalls. They are highly pleomorphic, with no fixed shape or size.Because of their plasticity, they can pass through bacterial filters and have often beenmistaken for viruses.Mycoplasmas do not possess spores, flagella, or fimbria. Some species exhibit glidingmotility. Mycoplasmas are gram-negative, but are better stained by Giemsa stain.

questions.question: Diene's method of staining is used for which of the following organisms?305
questions.explanation: Diene's method is used for mycoplasma.Mycoplasma shows a 'fried-egg' colony on Diene's method of staining. The central dark bluisharea represents the area of mycoplasmal down growth whereas the pale blue periphery indicatessuperficial growth of mycoplasma on the agar.

questions.question: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to which of the following antibiotics?
questions.explanation: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.Mycoplasma lack cell wall, and therefore, are inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics asthese drugs act on the cell wall.315
